div.head: “The Constellations: Northern, Some of the Zodiac, and Some of the Southern”
Title
div.p: In MS III, Ruskin wrote the title as “THE CONSTELLATIONS / NORTHERN, SOME OF THE ZODIAC AND / SOME OF THE SOUTHERN.” In MS IA, he wrote the title nearly identically, merely breaking the lines differently, as “THE CONSTELLATIONS NORTHERN / SOME OF THE ZODIAC / AND SOME OF THESOUTHERN.” In RF T70, the extension “NOTHERN . . . SOUTHERN is placed awkwardly, as if possibly inserted as an afterthought.
See System of Title Citation for Works.

div.head: Genre
div.p: Poem.

div.head: MS IA; MS III; RF T70
div.p: In MS III, a Red Book devoted initially to “Harry and Lucy . . . Vol 2”, “The Constellations” is the first poem in the MS III Second Poetry Anthology.
Facsimiles by permission of John Ruskin Collection, General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Transcriptions of texts and commentary © David C. Hanson.

div.head: Date
div.p: Initial composition (MS IA) and first fair copy (RF T70) sometime in the second half of 1827, probably in winter leading up to New Yearʼs 1828; revision and second fair copy (MS III) sometime after New Yearʼs 1828, probably in the first quarter of 1828.

The fair copy in MS III is undated. Its placement following the second volume of “Harry and Lucy” and before “The Sun”, both of which were completed for New Yearʼs 1828, suggests a similar period leading up to or following 1 January 1828 for “The Constellations”. Ruskin seems to set up the association in the prose section of “Harry and Lucy”, in which Harry gives Lucy a drawing of Charlesʼs Wain “as an introduction to astronomy”. Thus, Cook and Wedderburn, the editors of the Library Edition, may have been correct in listing the poem under 1827. More precisely, however, composition would have occurred in late 1827, although probably not as a New Yearʼs poem.

Cook and Wedderburn seem to intend an earlier 1827 date, associating the poem with the rough draft of “The Monastery” in MS IA, which they misdate as 1827 (Works, 2:535; and see “The Monastery”: Date). MS IA does contain rough draft of “Constellations”, but the editorsʼ grounds for associating this draft with the draft of “The Monastery” also contained therein can perhaps be neither confirmed nor denied, since a piece of that draft manuscript of “Constellations” is now very likely missing (see MS IA: Contents, b).

As internal evidence of dating, if Ruskin based portions of the poem on actual observation of the sky, the alignment of heavenly bodies described at the beginning of the poem would not have been possible in 1827, but rather would have to be moved forward to April‐May 1828, more in keeping with the occasion of John Jamesʼs birthday (see Discussion). However, to identify planetary movements accurately, Ruskin would need to have acquired sharper observational skills than simply finding Charlesʼs Wain circling the pole star.

div.head: Composition and Publication
div.p: Quoted in Ruskin, Works, 2:260 n. 1. Previously unpublished in entirety.

Another copy of the poem in Ruskinʼs hand is represented at the Ruskin Library by a photograph of a manuscript, RF T70, taken for the Library Edition but unused. Entitled “THE CONSTELLATIONS NORTHERN / SOME OF THE ZODIAC / AND SOME OF THE SOUTHERN”, the original manuscript in the photograph is otherwise unknown, as are the occasion and date of its original purpose. The most valuable information revealed about the original is that it presented a fair‐copy text that predated the MS III version. The RF T70 text runs the full length of the MS III version, but several lines, which Ruskin crossed out and replaced by revisions scrawled in the margins, are incorporated in their revised form into the text of the MS III version.

Moreover, the photograph RF T70 preserves a rare instance a manuscript that Ruskin evidently intended as a presentation copy but that he spoiled for that purpose with revisions—though whether he made the revisions before the original fair copy served its purpose, or after he had made some formal use of the manuscript, cannot be determined. The original manuscript consisted of a single folded sheet, with text fair—copied on two sides of a single leaf (pp. 1–2), leaving the other leaf (pp. 3–4) blank originally. The fair—copy text is print—lettered in a small hand, using pen and ink, thus dating the manuscript as no earlier than April 1827, when Ruskin first began adopted that medium (see The Ruskin Family Handwriting). Then, at some point after making this fair copy, Ruskin revised lines of the poem, using a cursive hand that is larger, sprawling, and freer than the original fair—copy lettering. He made his initial revisions in pencil and then in several cases overwrote the penciled cursive revisions using pen and ink in a cursive hand.

On the recto of the first leaf of RF T70 (p. 1 of the original fair—copy text), Ruskin wrote his revisions in the margin of the fair copy; and on the verso of that leaf (p. 2), he entered his corrections in the margin of the fair copy but extending across the fold into the facing page (originally blank). Here, too, he revised using pencil and then in some cases overwrote the revisions in ink. On the verso of the latter leaf (p. 4), he drafted revised lines in cursive using a pen. Pencil cursive text does appear beneath these pen—and—ink revised lines, but this handwriting belongs to a different text, unrelated to the poem.

Presumably, though not certainly, Ruskin made these revisions shortly before fair—copying the revised text in MS III, perhaps in late 1827—early 1828.
In fact, the original fair copy in RF T70, and not just its revisions, may have only shortly predated the MS III version—or at least the second page of the fair copy may have been significantly closer in time to the revisions. Starting at line 53 of RF T70, the fair‐copy hand suddenly appears larger, and Ruskin abandons the line numbering in the margin—suggestions perhaps that, at this point, Ruskin may already have decided to sacrifice this fair copy to revision (see also textual note for line 54). By comparison, the first page of the original fair copy shares characteristics with the earlier (1827) books 1–2 of “The Monastery” as compared the later (1828) books 3–4—the use of punctuation that is both more frequent and more eccentric, sprinkled with colons that seem more decorative than functional, and commas that float above the baseline.

div.head: Sources
div.p: Definitive evidence of one source of Ruskinʼs reading about the constellations is revealed in his “Harry and Lucy . . . Vol 2”, where Harry offers to “give . . . [Lucy] a drawing of charlesʼs wain as an introduction to astronomy”. The drawing, which Ruskin illustrates with his own drawing in the text, reproduces a diagram in volume 2, “Of Astronomy”, of Jeremiah Joyceʼs Scientific Dialogues. In Joyceʼs dialogue, the Tutor shows this diagram to his pupils, Charles and James, just as Ruskinʼs Harry presents the drawing to Lucy, as a first step in learning “‘how to distinguish the stars, and . . . call them by their proper names’”. He points out Charlesʼ Wain in the night sky, and describes the formation using the diagram—four stars forming a waggon, and three stars making the horses, all of them also forming part of a larger constellation, the Great Bear or Ursa Major. This constellation, he explains, can serve as a compass for finding oneʼs bearings at night, without the sunʼs position to define east and west. As a northern, circumpolar constellation, Charlesʼ Wain is always visible on a clear night; and as the diagram shows, it points to the North Star (i.e., Polaris) if one traces a line upward through the two stars forming the rear of the waggon. From this first point of reference, the Tutor proceeds to instruct Charles and James in the names and locations of other stars, constellations, and planets (Joyce, Scientific Dialogues, vol. 2, “Of Astronomy”, coversation 2, “Of the Fixed Stars”, 2:12–18, 250 opp. [pl. 1, fig. 1]).

In Ruskinʼs reading about the constellations, this episode in Joyceʼs dialogues formed a node of interlocking texts, for in Maria Edgeworthʼs Frank: A Sequel the Engineer marks passages in the Scientific Dialogues where Frank can find information about astronomy. Frank, in turn, recalls an episode in Thomas Dayʼs History of Sandford and Merton, in which “Harry Sandford found his way out of the moor by the help of the pole star” (Edgeworth, Frank: A Sequel, 2:141, 140). In Sandford and Merton, the tutor, Mr. Barlow, cites Harryʼs story of self‐preservation as an instance of practical uses to be derived from scientific understanding, an emphasis likewise imparted but with more detailed and sophisticated scientific information by the Tutor in Scientific Dialogues.

In Sandford and Merton, Tommy ensures they can find Charlesʼ Wain again by diagramming the stars on paper, and he carries on to conceive of a celestial globe in order to map all the constellations. Mr. Barlow obliges with a paper‐covered ball on which the boys can record their own observations of the constellations. While the emphasis is on practical and scientific knowledge, Mr. Barlow also encourages appreciation of natural beauty:

Mr. Barlow. Were there no other use, I should think there would be a very great pleasure in observing such a number of glorious, glittering bodies as are now above us. We sometimes run to see a procession of coaches, or a few people in fine clothes strutting about; we admire a large room that is painted, and ornamented, and gilded: but what is there in all these things to be compared with the sight of these luminous bodies that adorn every part of the sky?
(Day, The History of Sandford and Merton, 165, and see 162–69, 187–88)

The poem “The Constellations” is Ruskinʼs answer to to putting the constellations on paper. In context of Ruskinʼs own “Harry and Lucy . . . Vol 2”, the poem, along with Harryʼs drawing, effectively forms Lucyʼs “introduction to astronomy”; and in the context of Ruskinʼs reading about astronomy, the poemʼs seemingly mechanical exercise of listing the star clusters carries out the method, recommended by Mr. Barlow, of “remembering these stars [forming Charlesʼs Wain]” so that “you may very easily observe those which are next to them, and learn their names too, till you are acquainted with the whole face of the heavens” (Day, History of Sandford and Merton, 163). Just so, in Joyceʼs Scientific Dialogues, the Tutor instructs Charles and James in the names and positions of the constellations.

In his poem, Ruskin adopts the tactic of Dayʼs and Joyceʼs tutors by starting from a prominent point of reference—not, in Ruskinʼs case, a constellation, but a planet, Venus, the so‐called Morning Star and Evening Star, a wandering rather than a fixed star. He carries on to list the formations more or less in sequence, as do Dayʼs Tommy and Harry in drawing constellations on their globe. As a more sophisticated progression, Joyceʼs Tutor leads his pupils from the diagram of Charlesʼs Wain to a celestial globe, which he uses to orient the constellations to the ecliptic and equator; and then he directs the boys to an ephemeris, a catalogue of star positions (Joyce, Scientific Dialogues, vol. 2, “Of Astronomy”, conversations 2–4, 2:12–47). Modern ephemerides were based on exacting observations and mathematical computations, which were the pride of scientifically advanced nations that produced these star catalogues; however, their forbidding tables made the ephemerides a “primary culprit” in driving away public interest in astronomy, displacing the appeal to popular imagination that the stars had presented in the annual almanacs with a professionalization of the science that seemed inaccessible to omateur “sky‐loving men”, in Ruskinʼs phrase (Donnelly, “On the Boredom of Science”, 493–97).

Neither Joyceʼs nor Dayʼs books, however, lists all the constellations named in Ruskinʼs poem. For many of the names and attributes, he used a source that remains to be identified. In the editorial glosses to the poem, some connections are made with books known to have been owned by the family; for the present, the mythology associated with the constellations is glossed using an American text, Astronomical Recreations (1824) by Green.

div.head: Real‐life Observations
div.p: As indicated by Ruskinʼs sources, “The Constellations” is a bookish poem, interested more in poetic figures than in field observation. If works associated with New Yearʼs 1827, such as “Time: Blank Verse” and “Heights of Wisdom, Depth of Fools” [Miscellaneous Drawing, MS I] explore the poetic form of the emblem, works associated with New Yearʼs 1828 such as “The Constellations” explore poetic imagery such as naming objects in association with mythology. But the New Yearʼs poem “The Sun” also seems to reflect actual events, as do Ruskinʼs adaptations of Maria Edgeworthʼs lessons in his “Harry and Lucy” dialogues; and his verse novel, “The Monastery”, crosses history with the supernatural. To what extent does “The Constellations” involve actual observation of the sky?

Ruskin possibly derived some of his descriptions of constellations from actual observation of Venus, just as Joyce initially situates his fictional characters observing the evening sky at the end of a lingering walk. A planet is not an obvious starting point for charting the constellations, but the Evening Star and Orion present easy‐to‐find referents for ordinary observers.

According to a digital‐age ephemeris, Venus would have been visible from London as an evening star, setting in the west and appearing close to Orionʼs belt, in March‐May 1828. Mars would not have been visible high in the sky precisely at that time, but would have risen from the east somewhat later, after Venus had set. (An observer might also have confused MarsMars with the bright star, Sirius or “Dog Star”, in the constellation Canis Major directly below Orion.) This particular configuration of planets and constellations would not have appeared at any other time in 1828, and would not have been visible at all in 1827. Since Ruskin describes this configuration at the beginning of the poem, which he most likely composd in 1827, his description probably is not based on actual sky‐gazing—or at least not accurate observation.

Always visible, however, and easier to pick out of the night sky, are the northern constellations circling overhead. If the sequence of constellations listed in the poem reflects an actual evening observation, an observer could have looked up from Orion setting in the west, to Ursa Major (the Great Bear) overhead; following the “pointers” in Charlesʼs Wain, the observer would have found the tail of Draco (the Dragon) winding to the northeast; and then turning eastward, he would have encountered Corona Borealis (the Northern Crown) and Coma Berenices (Bereniceʼs Hair).

Hereafter, the sequence in the poem would have shifted an actual observerʼs gaze erratically around the dome of the sky. For Cygnus (the Swan), he would have turned back to the northeast, looking beyond Draco toward the horizon; and then to find Cor Caroli (Charlesʼs Heart), which is a star in Canes Venatici (Hunting Dogs), he would have turned in the opposite direction, back to the region of Corona Borealis and Coma Berenices (Sky & Telescope, Interactive Star Chart and Celestial Almanac, accessed 20 March 2022).

Beyond this point, the logic of Ruskinʼs repeated “next comes”, if the list represents any plan at all, maps a generally counter‐clockwise rotation, although the sequentially named constellations are not adjacent. The now obsolete constellation Herschellʼs Telescope, which was located within Auriga (the Charioteer), was adjacent neither to the previously named Cor Caroli (Charlesʼs Heart), nor to the subsequently named Equuleus (Little Horse), which lies between Pegasus and Delphinus. Continuing counter‐clockwise brings the viewer to Vulpecula; however, to get from Vulpecula to Lepus—from goose to hare—requires a full semicircle turn, either counter‐clockwise or clockwise (and a dip below the celestial equator, as well), and when Ruskin next shoots up to the pole star in Ursa Minor, all rationale for the arrangement seems lost. Perhaps Ruskin merely wanted to rhyme hare and bear, although, as suggested in the contextual glosses, he may have also have avoided violence by separating the Goose from the Fox in the combined constellation Vulpecula et Anser. have darted in different directions to find ; and so on Of course, if based on any actual observation at all, Ruskinʼs poem may reflect a mix of experience and information gleaned from a book or globe.

A distinct difference between Ruskinʼs poem and Joyceʼs dialogue is that Ruskin is interested in the poetic images evoked by the mythic names, whereas Joyceʼs Tutor and his scholars, while ready to quote illustrative poetry, are dismissive of what they regard as largely humbug: “James. ‘Why are the signs of the Zodiac called by the several names of Aries, Taurus, Leo, &c. I see no likeness in the heavens to Rams, or Bulls, or Lions, which are the English words for those Latin ones’. Tutor. ‘Nor do I’” (conversation 4, “Of the Ephemeris”, Scientific Dialogues, 2:36–37). In fact, a lesson that Joyceʼs Tutor dwells on is the arbitrariness underlying the naming systems of astronomy. The imagined patterns in the sky, whereby the Greek ordered and named the constellations, were arbitrary constructions, the Tutor emphasizes: “‘The ancients, that they might the better distinguish and describe the stars, with regard to their situation in the heavens, divided them into constellations, that is, systems of stars, each system consisting of such stars as were near to each other, giving them the names of such men or things, as they fancied the space which they occupied in the heavens represented’”. Charles takes the point: it is “perfectly arbitrary, that one collection is called the great bear, another the dragon; a third Hercules, and so on” (conversation 2, “Of the Fixed Stars”, in Joyce, Scientific Dialogues, 2:13–14). The arbitrariness of naming extends beyond the ancient constellations to modern systems: “‘If you look on the [celestial] globe’”, the Tutor continues, “‘you will observe, that . . . [lesser stars] are distinguished by the different letters of the Greek alphabet’”, which are also assigned arbitrarily (conversation 3, “Of the Fixed Stars, and Ecliptic”, Scientific Dialogues, 2:23).
